title: Race Condition in RPCDaemon dual mode?
body:
#### System information

Erigon version: 
 2021.08.1-alpha

OS & Version: Windows/Linux/OSX
CentOS 8
Commit hash : 
dfa2800a6ddf63ef9c7f6284fb6535b0f214736f
#### Expected behaviour
trace_transaction and eth_call to return within a reasonable time

#### Actual behaviour
iotop reports full SATA saturation of SSD drive ~225MBps, never returns any results.

./build/bin/rpcdaemon --datadir=/ssd/erigon/all_data --private.api.addr=localhost:9090 --http.api=eth,erigon,web3,net,debug,trace,txpool,shh --http.addr=0.0.0.0

./build/bin/erigon --datadir /ssd/erigon/all_data --maxpeers=10

Relevent logs (the entire node slows down, no errors):

#### Steps to reproduce the behaviour
Any trace_transaction will do:
curl -H "Content-Type: application/json" -d '{"jsonrpc":"2.0","method":"trace_transaction","params": ["0xf7e3d1cec88cf2d015e5d66b788daae2ae78835f56ec7359955c834e6cc8f843"],"id":1}' localhost:8545

@alysak6075 
- why do you call it "race condition"? 
- can you reproduce it? if yes, can you show output after `kill -6`?
- can't reproduce for now

"why do you call it "race condition"?"
that is what this issue was called in the discord support channel.

"can you reproduce it? " 
yes, every time,

"if yes, can you show output after kill -6?"
I decided to resync. After the node is caught up, I will try again, if issue persists I will show the output.

"can't reproduce for now"
neither can anyone else. Archivenode.io also returned the correct results. Thats why its so confusing.

Initial sync was done on v2021.07.01 and I usually update the node a few days after the thursday releases.  

When I rolled back to v2021.07.05 all calls returned as expected.

When I rolled forward to v2021.08.01 all trace calls and some eth_calls would never return if --datadir was passed to rpcdaemon 

without --datadir all calls would return, but they were about 5X slower then normal (I understand its because rpcdaemon did not have access to the DB directly.)

so interestingly: 
completely deleting the erigon dir and pulling the new devel branch solves this issue.
I did not edit the code and relied on git to make sure code was properly resolved against the repo.

is running: git checkout v2021-08-01

the incorrect way?
ah, if you have edited some file locally - then `git checkout v2021-08-01` will keep local changes. `git checkout -f v2021-08-01` will erase any local changes

"is it full output? looks not really full" that was all of it.
gcc (GCC) 8.4.1 20200928 (Red Hat 8.4.1-1)

anyways, the devel branch works fine:)

ah, if you have edited some file locally - then = well crap. I remember that when I was pulling that tag, continues integration was failing (you guys are lightning quick with fixes) so i figured i would pull the tag and then recheckout again when integration was passing. I did do the pull once integration was passed. I suppose git never overroad whatever was in my local dir.

User error strikes again. Thanks for the lesson! you can mark this as complete.
what an idiotic way to waste a week, sigh....
